There has not been a dearth of incendiary remarks from Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., who completed her first month in Congress on Feb. 3.

On Feb. 4, the House voted 210-199 to remove Greene from her appointments on the Education & Labor Committee and Budget Committee in response to an array of remarks that surfaced from before her time in office, showing a video of Greene harassing Parkland, Florida, school shooting survivor David Hogg and her engagement on Facebook with conspiracy theories and threats of violence against Democratic officials.
However, one controversial remark that many Facebook users have quoted Greene as saying is false.

A Facebook post from Jan. 31, which has now been shared over 750 times, reads: “‘If English was good enough for Jesus, it’s good enough for us.’ Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene on why Spanish should not be spoken in a Christian nation like America.”
In other viral posts, the statement is juxtaposed with a photo of Greene holding a rifle, a frame from a controversial campaign ad that Facebook removed.
These users did not respond to requests for comment.

Searches of Greene’s social media and Google showed she has never made this statement publicly. In addition, Greene has never commented on the speaking of the Spanish language in the U.S. or in U.S. schools.

Though the original poster of the meme could not be determined, the first mention of it in relation to Greene may have occurred on Twitter on Jan. 9, when a user compared the phrase to one of her tweets, which falsely stated that “The American People invented electricity, automobiles, airplanes, televisions, cellphones, and virtually every other incredible invention before social media.”

Variations of the statement have been misattributed to government officials for over half a century, but its origins have never been verified, as linguist Benjamin Zimmer detailed in a University of Pennsylvania blog post in 2006.

Because Jesus did not speak English, the quote is typically used to paint those officials as having a provincial or backward attitude, such as in this Los Angeles Times article from 1970. In the article, a member of the Mexican-American community implored social services employees to be more open-minded to the cultures of minority groups. "Montez ... illustrated the frequently-insensitive attitude in officials by recalling one public servant who told the group, 'If English was good enough for Jesus, it's good enough for us,'" says the article.

A version of the quote first appeared in an 1881 New York Times article, and since then, the statement has been most commonly attributed to Miriam Amanda “Ma” Ferguson, who served as the first female governor of Texas, from 1925-1927. "If the King's English was good enough for Jesus Christ, it's good enough for the children of Texas!" she is reported to have said, as relayed in a 2001 speech by former President Jimmy Carter.
In 2014, PolitiFact debunked Facebook users’ attribution of the quote to former Rep. Michelle Bachmann, R-Minn.

Based on our research, the claim that Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene said, "If English was good enough for Jesus, it's good enough for us" is FALSE. Searches of Greene’s social media and Google showed she has never made this statement publicly.
